awd_titl_txt: TC: Small: Defending against Insider Jammers in DSSS- and FH-Based Wireless Communication Systems
awd_abstract_narration: Jamming resistance is crucial for applications where reliable wireless communication is required, such as rescue missions and military operations. Spread spectrum technologies such as Frequency Hopping (FH) and Direct Sequence Spread Spectrum (DSSS) have been used as countermeasures against jamming attacks. However, these anti-jamming techniques require that senders and receivers share a secret key in order to communicate with each other. In situations where the adversary can compromise a legitimate communication device and learn the secret key, she can effectively defeat FH or DSSS wireless communication and thus disrupt normal network operations. In general, traditional anti-jamming techniques such as FH and DSSS are vulnerable to insider attacks where the adversary has access to the secret key used for anti-jamming wireless communication. This project develops novel and efficient insider-jamming-resistant techniques for both DSSS and FH-based wireless communication systems. This research consists of two thrusts: The first thrust develops novel spreading/despreading techniques to enhance DSSS-based wireless communication to defend against insider jamming threats, while the second thrust develops a new approach to enable FH-based wireless communication to be resistant against insider jammers. A key property of these new approaches is that they do not depend on any secret shared by the sender and receivers. This project will significantly enhance the resilience of future wireless communication systems, especially those for mission-critical applications that may face potential adversaries (e.g., rescue missions and military operations). The results obtained in this project will be disseminated through publications, graduate-level courses, and public release of software packages.

por.por_cntn:
With the proliferation of wireless communication systems, their security becomes a more and more severe concern. In particular, Jamming is a fatal threat to wireless communications. Due to the shared communication medium, a jammer can inject jamming signals to disrupt normal signal reception. In critical applications that require reliable and timely wireless communication (e.g., military operations, rescue missions), jamming resistance is a necessary property of the underlying wireless communication system. In this project, we seek to develop effective anti-jamming techniques in the presence of intelligent insider jammers, explicitly exploiting available features at the wireless medium and advanced signal processing techniques. The unique challenges we face are that the jammers potentially know everything about the communication systems and thus can do whatever a normal sender or receiver may do, and the jammers are assumed to possess the superior capability and intelligence promised by modern technologies such as cognitive radio, so that they can potentially monitor the environment and analyze wireless signals in real time.

Through this project, the following major research outcomes have been achieved towards our goal. First, we developed a novel DSD-DSSS scheme for efficient anti-jamming broadcast. DSD-DSSS achieves its anti-jamming capacity without pre-shared keys (to thwart insider jammers) in direct-sequence spread spectrum (DSSS) systems through randomly generating the spreading code sequence for each message using a random seed and delaying the disclosure of the seed till the end of the message. We also developed an effective protection mechanism for seed disclosure using content-based code subset selection. Our research indicates that DSD-DSSS is superior to all previous attempts for anti-jamming spread spectrum broadcast communication without shared keys. In particular, even if a jammer possesses real-time online analysis capability to launch reactive jamming attacks, DSD-DSSS can still defeat the jamming attacks with a high probability. Second, we developed a novel scheme for anti-jamming in frequency-hopping (FH) systems without pre-shared keys. Our USD-FH scheme transmits each message using a one-time pseudo-random hopping pattern and discloses the corresponding seed in an uncoordinated manner. The USD-FH scheme is validated through both theoretical analysis and simulation, and shown much more efficient and robust than previous solutions. Third, we developed the collaborative uncoordinated frequency hopping scheme (CUFH) to improve both communication efficiency and jamming resistance of UFH with the help of relay nodes. As all nodes in the network who have received the broadcast packets can serve as relays, the number of relays grows with time leading to an avalanche effect. Thus CUFH provides an appealing anti-jamming approach against insider jammers in large-scale networks. Fourth, we developed the multi-channel ratio (MCR) decoding technique, which provides an anti-jamming capability for multi-antenna wireless devices. Fifth, we exploited the mobility of network nodes as a new approach for jamming defense. Mobile intelligent jammers that can respond to the evasion of legitimate nodes are considered. Based on the solid foundation of spectral graph theory, our design enables the legitimate nodes to continuously reconfigure their geographic locations to recover the network performance, while presenting the adversary a dynamic and unpredictable attack surface. Sixth, in response to the growing intelligence and capability of the jammers, we undertook the game-theoretic approach to analyze the competing process, and facilitate the development of optimal defending strategies. When the system information is not readily available, we further employed reinforcement learning techniques to gradually learn the optimal strategies in practice. Finally, we explored a relevant research topic in which jamming is proactively exploited to disable unauthorized (enemy) wireless communications while at the same time maintain authorized communications.

This project has led to the publication of 9 journal papers and 22 conference papers on premium venues of IEEE, with two of them receiving best paper awards. It has also contributed several software packages to the community on wireless security, based on implementations of proposed anti-jamming techniques developed through this project.  This project has contributed to education through its impact on graduate course content in wireless communications and network security, through research seminars and invited talks (with one key-note speech at 2014 IEEE Conference on Communications and Network Security), and through participation in annual Engineering Open House, Senior Design Day, and Undergraduate Research Symposium at NCSU. This project has partially supported 8 PhD students; 5 of them have graduated, with 2 working in academia (University of South Florida and Lamar University) and 3 in industry (Qualcomm and Samsung). Researchers and students who worked on this project developed research skills in theoretical analysis (in particular in game theory, percolation theory, and graph theory), algorithm design (in particular in security mechanism design), experimentation with GNU Radio and USRP platforms, as well as obtained experience with emerging communication technologies such as 4G/5G cellular communications and cloud computing.
